Council chiefs have called for an immediate General Election amid warnings that the North East cannot afford the cost of Brexit.
Calls have been made for a new Government to step in because of what Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes labelled a ‘cack-handed’ approach to Brexit negotiations.
Coun Forbes told Wednesday night’s council meeting that a new Government is needed to deliver a better deal for Newcastle, as Nissan bosses cast fresh doubt over the future of its Sunderland factory after being left “in the dark” over Brexit. Cllr Nick Forbes (Image: Newcastle Chronicle)
He said: “We are the region worst hit in both a deal or a no deal scenario. Whatever the outcome of negotiations, the North East will be hit economically.
“Yet the Government fails to engage and talk to us in a meaningful way about the impact of Brexit and how we can mitigate it in our region.”
Lib Dem councillor Wendy Taylor had first raised a motion on Wednesday night calling for the British public to be given the final say on any Brexit deal - via a referendum which would also include an option to remain in the EU.
She told the chamber: “The warnings from Hitachi and Nissan should have been taken seriously. The North East needs their jobs and the prosperity they bring. British Prime Minister Theresa May arrives at the Council of the European Union (Image: Getty Images Europe)
“If it was democratic to reverse a referendum decision from 40 years ago, why is it to reverse one from two years ago?”
Leaked Government assessments indicated that the North East economy was predicted to shrink by 11%, even with a comprehensive trade deal and by 16% without one.
While Coun Taylor said she believed referendums are an ‘appalling’ way to take decisions, a second Brexit vote would be the only way to reverse the decision of 2016. Read More Nissan workers 'will never forgive us' if Brexit destroys their jobs
The council’s ruling Labour group voted through an amended version of her motion, in which Coun Forbes called for a meaningful vote in the House of Commons on the final Brexit deal and an immediate General Election.
He added: “I am really concerned that we will not end up with a deal. Some ministers in Government are actively preparing the ground for that and many right wing politicians would prefer us to leave the EU without a trade deal. That would be highly damaging to us here.” Like us on Facebook
